author: grapebaba
content: When the portal is integrated into the EL, the load of disk io and discv5 will increase a lot, so how to consider the impact on the EL when processing a large number of portal requests

author: grapebaba
content: <@510413979080720385> Does nimbus run into this kind of problem?

author: deme1744
content:
I haven't monitored this yet on an actual setup with CL + EL + Portal node, but I will do this somewhat soonish.
But I think this added load will be too low to cause any issues. When looking at our fleet nodes, they use a very low amount of CPU & memory. Disk access is only being pushed when pruning (we actually run 32 nodes per machine, so 32 nodes are hitting that same disk), but pruning will not occur in a EL + portal setup as we will have static radius. 

And sure, there will be extra discv5 activity but that is still very light weight compared to other p2p traffic going on. Of course, all depends on how many requests are happening on the network. But also there, this should be less than what we have seen so far as we might actually disable gossip (offer/accept) for the beginning?

author: deme1744
content: An other instance we have seen where our nodes would be pushed a bit more is when starting up with a 100% radius, as it would be receiving and processing everything initially. This is why this gets typically set to a lower, sane value. Still, it was able to handle this, but it is unnecessary load. And again, as we are using a static radius for EL integration, this conveniently becomes no longer an issue.

author: deme1744
content: We have some measures in place to avoid hitting the disk. Obvious ones such as doing the radius calculation before db lookup, and we have a recently accessed content cache.
